title: Have you ever sung along with a song only to find out later that you were singing the wrong words? What was your version? - Quora

response.answer_text: Okay, I am going to share a funny story. I am sure many have heard the song by War called “why can’t we be friends.” Probably one of the catchiest songs with a reggae like beat in the 70’s. I couldn’t understand the lyrics and thought they were singing “make it spic and span.” To my younger readers, spic and span was a popular floor cleaner at the time. I guess I saw enough commercials for it back then. For the life of me, I couldn’t figure out why they would be making such a catchy tune about a floor cleaner. Then again, I was about maybe 7 at the time too. LOL My parents finally corrected me that it was “why can’t we be friends.” Now this jogged my memory a little. Back when I was in school, we did have some occasional gospel songs in music class. One was “Joshua fought the battle of Jericho.” At the time, that melody was used in a commerical for Geritol. Again, to my younger readers, Geritol was a vitamin that was targeted at seniors. So, we would be singing this song along with the record and have to be reminded that it was “Jericho” and we were not singing about Geritol. I thought it sounded like the record was saying “Joshua fought the battle of Geritol and the walls came tumbling down.” Oh my, I can still hear the teacher say, “we aren’t singing about Geritol.” The first example, you never had a commercial made with that melody. Maybe that was a lost chance at a jingle now that I think of it. Or maybe I saw too much TV back then. LOL Who knows. Questions like this can be fun jogging the memory.

omg absolutely. I must’ve made this mistake several times. My grandfather would play a song called “Gold on the Ceiling” by The Black Keys. Little me would bop hard to this song. Here were what the actual lyrics were: “They wanna get my Gold on the ceiling I ain’t blind it’s just a matter of time” yadda yadda I thought that the singer said that they were gonna get their “rolls on the ceiling” as in the food. I didn’t question it whatsoever. Who wouldn’t want to steal someone’s rolls? Then, I thought, hm maybe these aren’t the lyrics…, and I came up with another wrong version. Instead, the singer sung about how they were going to roll around on the ceiling. A pretty funny visual if you ask me.

When I was much younger, I couldn’t get enough of the great music coming out of the sixties. So many artists were pushing the boundaries and breaking the norms that we were hearing things that seemed so fresh and new. One of those artists was Jimi Hendrix. His guitar work just felt so amazing and mind-bending, but he was also poetic in his lyrics. He did a song in 1967 called “Purple Haze” and I loved singing along with it and playing air guitar. I always felt a bit awkward and puzzled at the fourth line of the song when I sang along to “Excuse me while I kiss this guy.” It just wasn’t something you heard in pop music, but it was Hendrix, and he was known to be into mind-altering drugs, so I just blew it off and sang along with it anyway. It turned out his actual lyric was “Excuse me while I kiss —- the sky.” I didn’t find that out until many years later.

Not me but a friend.. Many years ago I was in a relationship with a guy who had a twin brother. We all hung out together and those two were hilarious. One day we were riding in the truck- I was in the passenger seat, my bf was driving and his brother was sitting in the back seat, behind me. At that time the INXS song “Suicide Blonde” was kinda popular and it wasn’t unusual to hear it on the radio and it was easy to sing along to. The chorus says something like “ You wanna make her a suicide blonde” but what I heard coming from the backseat was “You wanna make her a soup and salad bar”. 🤣🤣🤣 I don’t think I can ever sing the original lyrics again 🤣🤣🤣

This has happened to me soo many times! One of the times was in Defying Gravity (Wicked). The lyric is “So, it you care to find me, look to the western sky!” I would always changed the lyrics to “So if you can’t find me, look to the western guy!” I’m pretty sure that most people make that same mistake. :) In the song Somebody That I Used To Know (Gotye), the lyric is “Make out like it never happened and that we were nothing” and i always would sing “Make it out and hababababhbab we were nothing” :)

Tumbling Dice: Rolling Stones Here are some of the lyrics. With what I thought were the lyrics underneath in parentheses Mmm yeah! (Woo, woo) Women think I'm tasty, but they're always tryin' to waste me ( People think I’m lazy. Always trying to rate me) Make me burn the candle right down ( Ok I got this lyric correct) But, baby, baby, don't need no jewels in my crown' (But baby, baby, don’t be choosing no frown) Cause all you women is low down gamblersCheatin' like I don't know how (Got these right but getting 3/5 is not a good sign) Baby, got no flavor, fever in the funk house now (How can any one get, got no flavor is beyond me!) This low down bitchin' got my poor feet a itchin'Don't you know you know the duece is still wild While I love this song, boy sometimes the lyrics are unclear. Here is the video of the song.  Hope this helps or at least illuminates (or not) some of the lyrics!

I once owned a benefit CD from the 90s called “No Alternative”. I played it a lot in the car mostly because I was too lazy to change it out. One day my son (maybe 5–6 years old) asked me to play “Monkey Love”. I had no idea what he meant and he got upset with me for not knowing. Eventually a remake of the Rolling Stones song “Bitch” as performed by the Goo Goo Dolls came on. “That’s it! Monkey Love!” That’s when I realized he misheard the phrase “Must be love” as “Monkey love”. I wasn’t about to correct him with the true title so I let him go on thinking that.

So many times. An example would be “Before He Cheats” by Carrie Underwood. My mom rose me alongside country music and I’ve sung along since I was a kid but it wasn’t until maybe a few years ago I realized she sang “Maybe next time he’ll think before he cheats” rather than “Maybe next time he’ll fake”. Yikes. I had no idea why I thought those lyrics made sense but my thirteen-year-old self never questioned her.

When I was in highschool we were given a lot of activities where we needed to make a song usually we were allowed to adapt the tone of am existing song so we only had to worry about lyrics. I guess my brain was just so used to my version since I sang it so many times as practice for our performance and I realized I was singing the wrong words because I was with a friend walking around town when I started singing the song and he asked me why I was singing it wrong.

I did for twenty years until one-day I was singing while wearing headphones and someone pointed out to me that I had the words wrong. I was listening to Burning Love by Elvis Presley. At the point in the song where it says “You light my morning sky” is the spot where I had a word wrong. I had been using fire instead of sky. It only took me twenty years to get it right.

When I first heard the song “Africa” by Toto, I thought the lyrics were: It's gonna take a lot to take me away from youThere's nothing that a hundred men on Mars could ever do I mentioned to my son that I thought those were funny lyrics and he burst out laughing at me (kids like to laugh at their parents ….) For those who don’t know, the correct lyrics are: It's gonna take a lot to take me away from youThere's nothing that a hundred men or more could ever do :-)

Yes, in “Hotel California” I had always heard the line “warm smell of colitas” as “warm smell of the leaf grass”. Because I didn’t know the word colitas I guess. So about 10 yrs ago I was singing along with others at a song circle and they heard me sing that, and they all laughed and explained what the actual line was.

For years I sang “Hold me close I’m tired of dancing” instead of “Hold me closer tiny dancer” in Elton John’s ‘Tiny Dancer’. Getting my own lyrics wrong is a whole different story. I have a song called ‘4 Billion Bricks’ which is an anti-Trump song about immigration and family etc. etc. but there’s this one line where if I switch the rhyming words around it suddenly becomes incredibly racist instead of affirming, Somehow that’s my favourite place to slip up. I performed the song in my final masters recital and I swear half of our rehearsal time was spent with me just crying over that one line and how I could never get it right…

So you know the song Fight Song by Rachel Platten? Well this was my version: “This is my FIGHT SONG, My Ever light song, Come on let do Song!” So As you can see that is not correct lol. When I found out the real words i was like, Oh wow,. Stay Alive |-/

listen when I was in a rock band in high school my band mates would give me bubble gum about ten piece to chew so I wouldnt sing ..they kept giving me gum all night ,if I spit it out, they would quit playing until I would put more gum in my mouth. my drum kit look like hell had gum struck to it …every few weeks I had to scrap all the gum off of my kit just to make it sound like a drum set again ..they also would take my pay for the gig if I try to sing….

It's been years, but my family and I still laugh at how I murdered the lyrics from Bel, Biv & Devoe’s, “Smile Again.” Where they sang “’cause I know I meesd up, baby, and I know you're fed up, sugar,” I sang, “’cause I know you must, baby, and I know you better, sugar!” Nowhere near the right lyrics, but I sang them loud and proud! 😁😂😃

Boy Howdy did I ever. One such song was Bohemian Rhapsody. Don’t remember what I was singing but it sure wasn’t Bismillah or Beezelbub. I was lucky I got Figaro magnifico eventually. I can say for certain this wasn’t the only time but it is the most memorable.

Yes, Janet Jackson’s “Doesn’t Really Matter”. Her: “Doesn’t really matter what the eye is seeing, cuz I’m in love with the inner being” Me: ”Doesn’t really matter what the other’s believe, cuz I’m in love with the energy”

Hi Melanie Often!!! One I recall was A Whiter Shade of Pale, which for me started like this; ”The skipper light fandagled…”The song was so crazy, that whilst it didn’t make sense, sounded like that! For me the chorus sounded like,” And so it was, lady…”. There were lots of others, which I don’t recall.
Yes. On “Wake me up before you go go” by Wham, I thought the lyric was “You make the sun shine brighter on the darkest day” when it is actually “You make the sun shine brighter than Doris Day.”
Oh Yeah, As a kid, I was a big Rolling Stones fan, Jagger didn't always sing the words clear. I learned them wrong all the time.
